content.description: Start sitting with hands on good huecos on the right hand side of the boulder. Low traverse left on a fun line of huecos, then top out up the hueco groove.
content.location: This problem is located on the low boulders just east of the Big Time boulder.

content.description: Standing start, follow ledges up and right.
content.location: As you exit the Big Time area by walking through an opening between two boulders, this line will be on your left. It is on the same boulder as Little Big Time, just a little further south.

content.description: Start sitting and climb directly up the overhung face on crimps with a couple of fun throws. Left of Eye Gouger.
content.location: This problem is located on the low boulders just east of the Big Time boulder.

content.description:
This classic face climb is one of the more notorious highball problems at Hueco.  The excellent moves, stellar rock, and memorable finish make this problem a must do for those solid at the grade.  Despite the towering height of this problem, the crux is low, and the landing is excellent, so wait for a crowd, layer the pads thick, and go for it! 

  Begin matched in the large hueco 4 feet above the ground and 10 feet right of the NW arete of the Big Time Boulder.  The crux is the first three moves, and is quite safe with good pads.  Head up and left to an incut diagonal crimp and horizontal sloping crimp just above.  Work the feet, then dyno for the obvious pocket/crimp in the middle of the face.  From here, 6 or so more moves of V1/V2 crimping lead to a huge jug and easy mantle at the lip.  Descend the SE ridge.
content.protection: Many pads and a good spotter.
content.location: 8 feet right of the NW arete of the Big Time Boulder, on the West face.

content.description: Start See Spot, finish The Rack

Start on the obvious 2 handed 2 pad slightly incut crimp, awkwardly paste your feet on the wall and deadpoint up to the crack undercling.  Follow this crack right through underclings, fingerlocks and miserable feet. Work yourself on to the low angle right side of the boulder and step off. 

  If you start on the big hueco start hold for "See Spot Run" and work your way through some miserable crimps this is "Run the Rack" for V9 credit.
content.protection: A pad and a spotter to move it along.
content.location: On the impossible to miss Big Time Boulder.  Find the classic highball "See Spot Run" and move 5 feet to an obvious crimp.

content.description: Low crux. I found starting around the corner to the right to be more fun, but I think starting on the face is legit, too. Long moves on good holds if you start around the corner, shorter moves on crimps if you start on the face. Gets a little thin near the top, but not as hard as the start.
content.location: Walk into the alcove past See Spot Run, and as you walk around a hip high boulder, this problem will be directly in front of you before you exit the alcove.

content.description: Start low and climb directly up the overhung face on the northwest arete on excellent huecos.
content.location: This problem is located on the low boulders just east of the Big Time boulder.

content.description: This hand crack will give a great "crack workout", but watch your back.  Because the crack is on the wall of a fissure, any length of fall will hurt when you hit the wall behind.  Not safe for the cut-and-run style of leading, place lots of gear.  Seconding is bad too.  Consider only leading this. To clean, do a mix of down-aiding the crack and down-climbing the chimney.
content.protection: This crack increased from #.75 down low to #4 Camalots up high.  I use doubles from #1 to #4. Tape up your hands. Sharp crystals lurk in the upper wide section.
content.location:
Hike to the end of the chain trail and then to the Big Time area.  This overhung crack is on the left wall of the entrance fissure that connects the Big Time to the Gymnasium. 

  When setting up the belay, leave room for people to get by.  The entrance to the Gymnasium is very popular.

content.description: Start sitting left of the arete, MATCHED on the undercling, and figure out a sequence to traverse right into See Spot Run

Same start as Dark Age, go directly up to the obvious hueco, and either continue going directly up or move right into the upper section of See Spot. Correct me if I'm mistaken, I believe the original FA was by Sharma and done with the former exit.

The Big Time is a cluster of large boulders near the summit of North Mountain.  The size and configuration of the boulders provides for nearly all-day shade on most problems, making this a great warm weather destination.  Due to the size of these boulders, most of the lines are long.  The rock quality is excellent.
